Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2011 07:15AM llm005 wrote: Hi all, I live in the country and had to learn how to do the Neupogen.  The community nurse came and did it twice and then I was on my own.  Luckily the nurse was patient and wrote down all the steps.  I'm reasonably ok with needles AS LONG AS I DON"T HAVE TO LOOK AT THEM -- which of course you DO have to do to give yourself one.  The saving grace was that it was a very short needle.  Anyway, I did it.  And if I can do it, anyone can.  I just took it very slowly and methodically, and tried to give myself a little reward after each time. I was in fact quite proud that I was able to do it in the end, after being so terrified at the prospect of doing it that I could not sleep the night before the first time. Good luck!!

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2011 04:57PM - edited Oct 13, 2011 05:09PM by llm005 Hi Jerseylicious, After my first docetaxel (Taxotere) I ended up with febrile neutropina (fever, no WBC) and spent 6 days in hospital, 4 on intravenous antibiotics.  No source of infection was ever found.  It took a few days for the fever to go down, but it did in the end.  I can completely understand your friend's fear.  I was very worried when the antibiotics had been flowing in, but nothing was happening to the fever.  But it DID go down after a couple of days, would bump up again a bit, and then down again.  They kept me on the IV antibiotics for a couple of days after, and when I was sprung from the hospital, I continued on oral antibiotics for two weeks.  Apparently this happens to about 25% of those on docetaxel.  I had to take neupogen for my next two rounds of it to stimulate my bone marrow into producing WBC.  And I didn't have this problem again. I hope everything goes well for your friend.  Tell her to hang in there.
